title: Ireland-Bristol Trade in the Sixteenth Century
abstractText:
This project examines changes in the size and structure of Ireland’s sixteenth century trade with Bristol.  The aim is to throw light on the development of the economy of southeast Ireland, which was then the most developed region of the country.  The study extends the results of unpublished analyses by the project team.  This work suggests that the economy of southeast Ireland became more commercially and industrially orientated during the first half of the sixteenth century.  The project seeks to determine the nature and dimensions of this expansion and to reveal when and why it came to an end.

The main source for the study are the ‘particular’ customs accounts / Port Books of Bristol. These record what was the most important branch of Ireland’s overseas trade in minute detail. Customs accounts covering nine individual years, spaced across the sixteenth century, will be inputted into a computer database and analysed by the researchers. This data is invaluable because poor record survival mean that no other economic records of equivalent value survive in Ireland, or elsewhere.  The Bristol customs accounts thus constitute the best quantitative source that exists for examining Ireland’s economic development over the course of the sixteenth century.
